awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Computational Photo-Scatterography: Unraveling Scattered Photons for Bio-Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
Much of the success of today's healthcare is due to rapid advances in our ability to collect and analyze high-resolution data about the human body. However, current methods to achieve cellular resolution are invasive (e.g., blood test or tissue biopsy), and non-invasive imaging modalities do not achieve cellular resolution. The principal goal of this Expeditions project is to develop computational imaging systems for non-invasive bio-imaging, deep beneath the skin, and at cellular-level resolutions. This project has the potential to fundamentally impact healthcare and medicine, by enabling live views of cross sections of human anatomy, simply by pointing a camera at any part of the body. This would put individual users at the center of their healthcare experience and make them true partners in their healthcare delivery. The health imaging devices that result from this project will act as an important pillar in the personalized medicine revolution. This research expedition also holds the potential to launch new healthcare paradigms for chronic disease management, pediatrics, low-resource healthcare, and disaster medical care. Beyond healthcare, making progress on the problem of cellular-scale deep-tissue imaging using light will push the frontiers of the fundamental problem of inverse scattering, which impacts numerous areas of science and engineering. The order of magnitude advances made in inverse scattering and imaging through scattering media will have significant cross-cutting applications in diverse areas such as basic science, consumer imaging, automotive navigation, robotics, surveillance, atmospheric science, and material science. Finally, projects with a single, easy-to-appreciate, and high-impact goal have the potential to inspire the next generation of scientists, attract diverse set of students driven by humanitarian and social causes, and become a platform for inclusion and innovation.

The overarching goal of this project is to develop, test, and validate new computational imaging systems, to non-invasively image below the skin at tunable depths, in highly portable form-factors such as wearables or point-of-care devices. The main challenge is that light scatters as it travels through the human body, and in this process, the spatial information from different points within the body gets mixed up. A new concept, Computational Photo-Scatterography (CPS), is being applied in this project in order to computationally unravel the scattered photons in an imaging system, and allow creation of sharp images and accurate inferences. Recognizing that the brute-force complexity of unraveling scattered photons is prohibitively high, the project uses a computational co-design framework that leverages advances by team members from multiple domains: programmable illumination and optics, image sensors, machine learning, inverse graphics, and hybrid analog-digital computing.  The project will use machine learning (ML) instead of physics-based de-scattering to speed up the solution of the underlying inverse problem. A combination of physics-based inverse graphics algorithms, and ML algorithms combining deep learning and generative modeling will be used to estimate tissue scattering parameters -  motion due to blood flow induces time-variation in tissue parameters, which makes solving the inverse scattering problem more difficult. The project will use ML to create fast but approximate estimators, which will serve as accelerators for inverse scattering. The development of new sensors, able to capture the data necessary to reconstruct the structure of the tissue deep below the skin, constitutes the most important contribution of the project. These systems and algorithms will have the potential to break the current resolution limits of noninvasive bio-imaging by nearly two orders of magnitude, enabling cellular-level imaging at depths far beyond currently possible.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Motivation and Goals

Much of the success of today's healthcare is due to rapid advances in our ability to collect and analyze data about the human body. However, current methods for cellular-level analysis are invasive, often involving extraction of a sample (e.g. blood test or tissue biopsy). The complexity and cost of many invasive tests puts them out of reach for many patients and increases the complexity of healthcare. While there exist a host of non-invasive measurement modalities (X-ray, MRI, fMRI, PET, etc.), only light-based systems are non-ionizing, potentially high-resolution and portable. Unfortunately, while a large amount of light can pass through human tissue at significant depths, nearly all photons are scattered, which often makes subsequent analysis impossible. Consequently, today's light-based diagnostic systems have made few inroads into non-invasive cellular-level analysis.

Intellectual Merits: 

This project has developed a new paradigm --- Computational Photo-Scatterography (CPS) --- which computationally unravels the scattered photons to create sharp images and accurate inferences. The results show that CPS has the potential to break the current resolution limits of light-based non-invasive bio-imaging by an order of magnitude, in both depth and resolution of imaging. Recognizing that the brute-force complexity of unraveling scattered photons is very high, CPS is a computational co-design framework that leverages advances by team members from multiple domains: programmable illumination and optics, image sensors, machine learning, inverse graphics, and hybrid analog-digital computing.

Based on this approach, the project developed new camera technologies, called “photon-path cameras”, that can measure not only the spatial and spectral distribution of photons but also based on their polarization, angle, phase, and arrival time. Using novel computational optics, these technologies produce sharper images by unscrambling scattered photons that travel deeper within tissue to focus on regions of interest. Further, multiple works in the project show that controlling light propagation in tandem with sound (ultrasound) or heat transport improves performance and depth achieved further. 

The PIs and their groups have developed fast inverse algorithms that convert the measurements of the photon-path cameras into inferences regarding the most relevant parameters for tissue imaging. All above works have collectively improved diffuse optical tomography, optical coherence tomography, acousto-optics and other light-based technologies used commonly for bio-optical imaging for tissue estimation. To manage the complexity of our inference algorithms, the project developed methods to perform large but energy-constrained computations using a combination of analog and digital hardware. The project also developed approaches that provide a framework for privacy preservation in user-device groups.

In summary, the research in this project forms the foundation for future non-invasive diagnostic methods for an increasing number of health conditions by driving the high quality imaging deeper within tissue.

Broader Impacts:

Collectively the PIs have attracted, advised, and trained large and diverse groups of personnel throughout the duration of the project at all levels from high-school to undergraduate, graduate and post-graduate. The results of the research culminated in multiple Masters and PhD theses and completed students and postdocs have begun their careers in academia and industry. The research jumpstarted several interdisciplinary collaborations with health-care professionals. The research resulted in multiple inventions that lead to patent applications and follow up discussions with industry on licensing for commercialization. Multiple start up companies arose from the research across all partner institutions, including, one spun-off from Carnegie Mellon University.

The multi-disciplinary research was disseminated via top scientific conferences and journals in many fields including computer vision, optics, computer graphics, machine learning, systems, health-care, and others. Many works have won prestigious awards at highly competitive conferences, where only a few awards are given to papers selected from over ten thousand submissions. The research has been integrated into several educational activities including week-long summer courses for high-schoolers, to conference workshops, tutorials, seminars, invited talks and semester-long courses in degree programs.

Inspired by the research in this project, the center for computational scatterography is further sustained by multiple large translational and synergistic efforts that have already started or are about to start.  Examples include: (1) a cancer imaging project to improve surgical precision ensuring all of the tumor is removed and increasing patient survival rates, (2) a project to develop an autonomous robotic first responder medic that triages injured personnel in disaster zones, (3) a project to improve precision and resilient agriculture as part of an AI Institute, and (4) a project to develop a robotic backpack that autonomously provides critical care in the battlefield and disaster scenarios.
